subject: Aerospace Engineering
question_text:
Sourya committee had proposed the establishment of Sourya Institutes of Technology (SITs) in line with Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) to cater to the technological and industrial needs of a developing country.
Which of the following can be logically inferred from the above sentence?
Based on the proposal,
(i) In the initial years, SIT students will get degrees from IIT.
(ii) SITs will have a distinct national objective.
(iii) SIT like institutions can only be established in consultation with IIT.
(iv) SITs will serve technological needs of a developing country.

tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires logical inference from a given statement. It involves understanding the implications of the proposal and selecting the correct inferences from the options provided. It requires multiple steps of reasoning to evaluate each option.

answer_validation.reasoning:
The core statement is: 'Sourya committee had proposed the establishment of Sourya Institutes of Technology (SITs) in line with Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) to cater to the technological and industrial needs of a developing country.'

Let's evaluate each inference:
(i) 'In the initial years, SIT students will get degrees from IIT.' The phrase 'in line with IITs' implies a similar model, standard, or objective, but it does not imply a direct affiliation for degree granting. This cannot be logically inferred.
(ii) 'SITs will have a distinct national objective.' The statement explicitly says SITs are proposed 'to cater to the technological and industrial needs of a developing country.' This directly implies a national objective. This can be logically inferred.
(iii) 'SIT like institutions can only be established in consultation with IIT.' Similar to (i), 'in line with IITs' suggests following a similar structure or standard, but it does not imply a mandatory consultation or approval process from IITs for establishment. This cannot be logically inferred.
(iv) 'SITs will serve technological needs of a developing country.' The statement clearly states SITs are proposed 'to cater to the technological and industrial needs of a developing country.' This is a direct restatement of the purpose and is a logical inference.

Therefore, only inferences (ii) and (iv) are logically correct, making option C the correct answer.

step_by_step: Carefully read and understand the given statement: 'Sourya committee had proposed the establishment of Sourya Institutes of Technology (SITs) in line with Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) to cater to the technological and industrial needs of a developing country.'
Analyze each inference option (i-iv) individually to determine if it can be logically concluded solely from the given statement, without introducing external assumptions or knowledge.

Evaluate inference (i) - 'In the initial years, SIT students will get degrees from IIT.' The phrase 'in line with IITs' suggests a similar model or standard, not a direct affiliation for degree issuance. There is no information in the statement to support this claim. Hence, (i) is not a logical inference.

Evaluate inference (ii) - 'SITs will have a distinct national objective.' The statement explicitly mentions that SITs are proposed 'to cater to the technological and industrial needs of a developing country.' This directly implies that SITs will have a national objective focused on the country's development. Hence, (ii) is a logical inference.

Evaluate inference (iii) - 'SIT like institutions can only be established in consultation with IIT.' The phrase 'in line with IITs' refers to adopting a similar framework or quality, not a requirement for consultation or permission from IITs for establishment. This is an over-inference. Hence, (iii) is not a logical inference.

Evaluate inference (iv) - 'SITs will serve technological needs of a developing country.' The statement clearly states that the purpose of SITs is 'to cater to the technological and industrial needs of a developing country.' This is a direct and undeniable inference from the given text. Hence, (iv) is a logical inference.
Based on the analysis, only inferences (ii) and (iv) are logically valid. Therefore, the correct option is C, which includes both (ii) and (iv).

topic.name: Logical Reasoning
topic.syllabus_ref: GATE General Aptitude Syllabus - Verbal Ability (Reading Comprehension, Logical Deduction)

essential: Ability to understand and interpret English text accurately.
Basic principles of logical deduction and inference.

Main Concept: requires: Understanding of English grammar and vocabulary
requires: Ability to distinguish between direct statements and assumptions
enables: Critical analysis of textual information
enables: Effective decision-making based on given facts

difficulty_factors: Requires careful reading to avoid over-inference and reading beyond the given information.
Distinguishing between direct implication and external assumption, or bringing in outside knowledge.

textbook_references.book: Aerospace Engineering: A Textbook for Undergraduate Students
textbook_references.author: Satya Bir Singh
textbook_references.section: 9.2 Role of Government in Aerospace Development
textbook_references.text_snippet: This chapter discusses the importance of government involvement and national objectives in shaping the aerospace industry and education system of a country, especially in the context of developing nations.

textbook_references.book: A Modern Approach to Verbal & Non-Verbal Reasoning
textbook_references.author: R.S. Aggarwal
textbook_references.text_snippet: An inference must be based solely on the information given in the statement, not on assumptions or outside knowledge.

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Parse Statement -> Identify Key Information -> Evaluate Each Inference Against Statement -> Eliminate Unsupported Inferences -> Select Correct Option
key_insights: Stick strictly to the information provided in the statement.
Avoid making assumptions or bringing in external knowledge.
Distinguish between 'in line with' (similarity) and 'dependent on' (necessity).

formulas_principles.name: Principle of Logical Inference
formulas_principles.conditions: For an inference to be valid, it must be directly supported by or necessarily follow from the given premises.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core principle for solving this question.

industry_examples: Analyzing technical project proposals to separate stated goals from unsupported assumptions.
Analyzing legal texts and contracts to determine exact implications.
Understanding project scope and objectives from initial statements in engineering management.
specific_systems: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) as an example of a national institution serving the aerospace needs of a developing country
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: The ability to logically infer conclusions from given statements is crucial for critical thinking, effective communication, and accurate decision-making in academic, professional, and daily life. It is important for engineers in roles requiring technical documentation review, project planning, and policy analysis, as misinterpretation can lead to incorrect actions or misunderstandings.

common_mistakes.mistake: Over-inference or making assumptions not explicitly stated, such as assuming SIT students will get IIT degrees based on 'in line with IITs'.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Students tend to over-interpret the provided information, bringing in common knowledge or personal opinions, and making unsupported assumptions, extending the meaning of the statement beyond what is directly implied.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Carefully read the question and the given information. Only select options that can be directly inferred or reasonably deduced from the provided context, strictly sticking to the given words. Avoid over-inference by asking if the inference is *directly* supported by the statement.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrectly selecting options that are plausible but not logically derivable, leading to loss of marks.

common_mistakes.mistake: Misinterpreting nuanced phrases like 'in line with', failing to distinguish between logical inferences and personal opinions or additional assumptions (e.g., believing 'in line with' means 'only with consultation of' IIT).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Phrases like 'in line with' can be ambiguous, leading students to interpret them as requiring direct approval or dependency, rather than merely similarity in model or standard. This reflects a difficulty in separating factual information from subjective interpretations or adding extra conditions not present in the statement.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Pay close attention to the precise meaning of words and phrases, critically analyzing each option. Recognize that terms like 'in line with' indicate similarity or alignment, not necessarily a direct hierarchical relationship, mandatory consultation, or procedural requirement. Ensure inferences are logical consequences of the given information, not unsupported assumptions.
common_mistakes.consequence: Drawing incorrect conclusions about relationships or requirements, leading to selection of incorrect options.
Might omit a correct inference and choose the wrong option.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Consider the broader implication: An institute established to cater to national technological needs inherently has a national objective, distinct from purely local or private objectives.
common_mistakes.mistake: Missing a valid inference, such as overlooking that serving national needs implies a distinct national objective.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Students might think the inference is too vague or not explicitly stated.

mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When analyzing a proposal or statement to determine what can be logically inferred

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: SIT for National Tech: SITs Serve Nation's Technology (Inferences ii & iv).
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Helps remember the two correct inferences: national objective and serving technological needs.

flashcards.front: What is the primary rule for logical inference questions?
flashcards.back: Only infer what is explicitly stated or directly and undeniably implied by the text. Do not introduce outside information or make assumptions.
Strictly limit your conclusions to the given text. If the text doesn't provide enough information, you cannot infer it. Avoid 'what if' scenarios.

flashcards.front: What does 'in line with X' typically mean in a proposal?
flashcards.back: It means following a similar model, standard, or objective as X, aiming for comparable quality or structure. It does not imply direct dependency, affiliation, or a requirement for X's approval.

A logical inference is a conclusion that can be directly drawn from the provided information, without making additional assumptions. An unsupported assumption goes beyond the given context and introduces new ideas or interpretations that are not warranted by the information provided.
flashcards.front: What is the key difference between a logical inference and an unsupported assumption when analyzing a given proposal or statement?

real_world_context.industry_example: The creation of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) by the Indian government to develop the country's space technology capabilities and support its space program.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Accurate interpretation ensures compliance and effective implementation, avoiding missteps based on false assumptions.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: These questions are usually quick if you read carefully. For each option, mentally check if it's a 'must be true' based *only* on the statement. If there's any doubt or need for external info, it's likely not an inference. Quickly identify key information and eliminate obviously wrong inferences. Aim for ~2 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck or unsure, eliminate options that introduce new information, strong claims, or unsupported assumptions not explicitly stated or logically derivable from the text. Prioritize options that directly rephrase or are a clear, direct consequence of the stated information.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate 1-3 minutes per question. Read the statement once for overall understanding, then read each inference and compare it directly to the statement.

search_keywords: how to solve logical inference questions
Sourya committee SIT IIT inference question

alternative_methods.name: Identifying Assumptions vs. Logical Inferences
alternative_methods.description: Instead of directly analyzing the options, first identify the key information provided in the question and then systematically evaluate each option to determine whether it is a logical inference or an unsupported assumption.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Helps avoid the common mistake of making unsupported assumptions. Cons: May take more time compared to directly analyzing the options.

alternative_methods.name: Negation Test
alternative_methods.description: For each inference, consider its negation. If the negation contradicts the given statement, then the inference is valid. If the negation can coexist with the statement, the inference is not valid.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Rigorous logical test. Cons: More time-consuming for multiple-choice exams.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When you are uncertain about an inference and have time to analyze deeply.

connections_to_other_subjects.Philosophy: Formal logic, propositional and predicate logic, identifying valid and invalid arguments.
connections_to_other_subjects.Law: Statutory interpretation, contract law, drawing precise conclusions from legal texts.
connections_to_other_subjects.Computer Science: Boolean logic, artificial intelligence (knowledge representation and reasoning).
connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Economics: The role of government in funding and supporting technological development is closely linked to the economic considerations and policies of a country.
connections_to_other_subjects.Public Policy: The establishment of specialized institutions like the IITs and ISRO is a matter of public policy, involving decision-making, resource allocation, and alignment with national priorities.

deeper_dive_topics: Types of logical fallacies (e.g., ad hominem, straw man, false dilemma)
